I am pretty conflicted about whether I should recommend this game or not, and overall, I think this is one of those cases where there should be a â€œmixedâ€ option when writing a review, since my recommendation is VERY conditional: 

To start, this is a traditional, turn-based JRPG that feels 30 years old in many ways, and as far as I know, this was fully intentional, since â€œDragon Quest is not supposed to changeâ€ or something like that... 

For me, the beginning of the story was very slow - it felt like it took forever to actually get somewhere, but the game had this sort of â€œcharmâ€ that made it hard to fully put down, so I ended up playing through it over a couple of months, and my opinion is that if you go in knowing what kind of experience to expect, this can be a rather fun playthrough. 

Story-wise there is not much to (even accidentally) spoil, the game is very by-the-book, and it does not try to reinvent the wheel. In its own way, this can be somewhat refreshing, since even old cliches can seem new if most stories you encounter nowadays try to avoid them. 

The first 2 Acts of the game are fine and mostly tell a complete story, with some questions left unanswered. Act 3 is (somewhat) optional, and I personally think you do not lose a lot if you just watch the remainder of the story on YouTube, since Act 3 requires a significant amount of repetitive grinding if you want to get through it.  

Some of the companions have quite interesting character arcs, but I have a very negative opinion of the way they handled the main character, since he's an odd mix between a premade character with personality and a character you can make choices for. Problem is, he is neither. The Luminary has seemingly no personality, and the only sounds he makes are limited to grunts in pain or confirmation, and other than these, he has no voiced lines. Also, you only have Yes/No options, and even then, the game railroads you into the choice you have to pick to progress the plot, meaning that your companions scold you if you make the â€œwrongâ€ choice, and force you to pick the â€œrightâ€ option. 

Graphically, this is a stylized game with somewhat anime-like aesthetics, and while I was not exactly a fan of most of the character designs, this is a very subjective topic, and you might like them. 

Environmentally, most areas look fine, and there are some quite beautiful standouts. 

The music... I was not a fan of. At best, I can call it serviceable, but it was very repetitive, and the quality of most tracks was substandard.  

Around 15 hours into my playthrough, I found out that you can change the exploration music to the music from Dragon Quest VIII, and those tracks were a lot more pleasant to listen to. 

Overall, I do not think that there is much of a point in me rating this on a 0 to 10 scale, since I have very, very mixed opinions, but I also do not think that a 6 or a 6.5 is fair. My recommendation is that if you go in knowing what kind of experience you are going to get, then you can have some fun, and maybe even experience some nostalgia if, in the past, you used to play older-style JRPGs similar to this. Also, in case you need something to unwind to while you are listening to podcasts in the background, even Act 3 can be enjoyable, but I do not recommend playing through that part of the game, or trying to 100% it without a â€œsecond-monitor activityâ€ for the grinding parts.

The beautiful art direction that almost made me feel like I was inside a Ghibli Film, with all of its vibrant colors, and its cartoony artstyle. But everything was dragged down by its gameplay. I don't know if I was just playing it wrong, or its just how the game is designed, but I HATED the combat. The character building was fine, but the whole turn based system was boring, and very grindy. I don't have issues with grinding as long as I'm having fun, I love grinding in Shin Megami Tensei, or other turn based games... But this one? it felt so boring. I was doing fine, farming "just enough" to continue with the story, but there was a point where it felt I was just falling behind the enemies, plus I felt that I was alwaing using the same attack (the one that dealt most damage at the time). Things became more interesting by the end of the game, once I had a somewhat decent build for my characters, but still... Compared to other turn based games... The Grinding wouldn't be so bad if the animations weren't so long. I dont understand the idea behind being able to walk around during the battle, because... it doesn't do anything. It's just turn based, doesn't matter where you choose to stand.

The music is VERY Iconic, but that's about it. too many tracks repeat. Persona 5 came out a year before this and makes this game feel like its literally an NES title. 

Leveling is far too slow, and it felt like I would need to grind for hours just to level and get nothing of value, the skill tree is super basic and feels like it takes years to get something meaningful.

The story is just okay (I wish it hooked me sooner, 17 hours is enough.) It feels so clunky. I even tried swapping to 2D mode to see if I'd be interested in this game and it still did nothing for me.

Story is bad. Like... really bad. They make it like "big surprise!" but those twists are telegraphed 2 hours in advance. The characters make stupid choices non-stop too. The combat system is completely unexciting too. It is very straight forward and I like that to some extent but there's a bunch of poorly designed elements in it. Like how, your characters move in a circle but it has almost no effect on the combat itself. May as well have them in a fixed place.(would actually have been better) It can be challenging but not in an intellectual way.
A lot of poor designs like having to look at a text box telling you that the door is locked when your character made a physical action indicating that the door was locked a second earlier.
TLDR: game is tedious, not difficult due to poor design.(increase in difficulty would still not make it harder intellectually speaking) Story is downright irritating at times (middle-schooler's first attempt at writing a story. Looking at your Mermaid story ark)
Should not have had to pay full price again for a dlc. Remaster 8 and charge 90 bucks if you're that money hungry
